body.p:
Knowing the deep interest
you manifest in every thing appertaining to our
people I have selected this opportunity ofor
giving you an outline of the causes which
lend to the present excitement and anarchy
in our congregation. While I deeply deplore
the circumstances which have lead to the above results I cannot but beleive that the final
result will be beneficial, and will tend towards
showing to the world that if a few zealous
& perhaps well meaning men rashly break down
the essentials which support our Holy Religion
there are those (and many of them) who will cling to
it the more closely the greater the attempts to
innovate & reform it. You cannot reform the
Jewish Religion—it is an absurdity. There
are but two Religions taught in the Bible
Judaism & Christianity if you break down
the fences which support the former &
which were built up by an almighty arm
you must necessarily enter upon christian
Ground. Every unbiased & reflecting mind
will acknowledge this a just conclusion.
But I shant tire your patience with any

more remarks. But will relate the unhappy events
which have just transpired

You are perhaps aware there are about 70
Yechidim (voters) of our congregation—among that
member there are 18 or 20 ultra Reformers, about
the same number satisfied with the present
service & the Balance willing to go back to our
old mode of service—although not objectionable
but fearing further charges.

On the first day of the last
passover the Rev G. Poznanski delivered an English
discourse commemorative of the day &c. and at the
close of the discourse spoke of the useless observance
of the second day, that the exact time was now
known & this being known positively by our almanacs
the observance therefore of the second day was
altogether useless & unnecessary. This annunciation
caused great excitement and dissatisfaction
8 or 9 persons (among whom was Mr Moses) walked out
of the Synagogue. The matter was talked of
incessantly & discontent prevailed to an alarming
extent. The Trustees met & a Preamble & Resolution
discountenancing the action of Mr Poznanski was
made & carried at this meeting of the Board. While in session
a letter was received from Mr Poznanski regretting
the excitement produced—claiming a prerogative
that as the Trustees had requested him to

Bretheren who were driven from the old Synagogue
applied for Readmission with the privilege of a
vote. The opposite party heard of this fact
for it was not done secretly, & when 3 Trustees
applied to the President Abraham Ottoler? to
call a meeting (in accordance with the Constitution) to
elect a President these gentlemen, The President
refused to do so stating that a Petition had
been presented to him signed by a constitutional
member to call a public meeting—which he
must do & that after said meeting he would call
the Trustees together.

I must here observe that to call
a public meeting for general purposes one third of
the Congregation petitionary to the President he is
empowered to call it. But to alter the Constitution
one fourth of the congregation must petition to the
Board of Trustees, before whom the petition
must come for that purpose—when these gentl could have been elected

The meeting was called, The President stated
he called the meeting in consequence of a Petition
received signed by 26 members and would
be happy to hear any remarks &c.

Mr. I N. Cardoza the editor rose
& proposed the following Resolutions or rather
the Basis of them I do not give the
words.

Resolved That the will of the majority is the fundamental
law of all societies—civil political & Religious—

Resolved That the Trustees were elected under
the implied assurance they would recognize this right

Resolved that sufficient presumptive evidence
has been given to show that 4 out of the 7 of the
Trustees—(I will give their names Abm. Tobias Sol Moses
Isaiah Moses & Isaac Woolf) wish to elect a
body of men termed seceeders whose aim is to break
down the service now established & to turn out
the Hazan, thus making a majority yield to
the wishes of a minority.

Mr Cordoza endeavoured to sustain
these Resolutions with real federal sophistry—
Mr. Tobias answered him very ably and told
him they were unconstitutional.

The last Resolution suspended the power
of the Trustees & placed the government in
the hands of the Prest & 5 men selected
by him. It was here Mr Tobias noticed
its unconstitutionality and told him that
the meeting was not called for to alter the
constitution, to be so, the Petition should come
before the Trustees. This was argued at
great length, some avowing their determination
to trample on the constitution, & return to
arnachy & nullification.
